thread.title: Back to Work: Football teams return to the field
thread.title_full: Back to Work: Football teams return to the field

author: E. Marcel Pourtout mpourtout@neighbornewspapers.com (noreply@neighbornewspapers.com)
title: Back to Work: Football teams return to the field
text: Back to Work: Football teams return to the field by E. Marcel Pourtout October 14, 2015 02:56 PM | 154 views | 0 | 0 | Staff / Kathryn IngallNorth Springs player Justin Ruiz breaks a tackle from a Kell defender in a contest earlier this season. slideshow The prep football season enters its ninth week with several intriguing matchups this Friday and Saturday.Holy Innocents’ will host Lovett in a Region 6AA contest. The Golden Bears will look to earn its first region win after dropping their first three tries to gain one this season. Holy Innocents’ dropped their road contest to B.E.S.T. Academy 31-0 on Oct. 2.Lovett has fared better of late after going winless in non-region play. The Lions have won their first two region games with a 38-6 victory at B.E.S.T. Academy and a 47-6 home triumph over K.I.P.P. Atlanta. The latter contest saw the Lovett defense hold the opponent to minus-20 yards rushing and 57 yards of total offense in the win.Lovett has won all three previous meeting against Holy Innocents’ including last year’s 42-13 home victory.Riverwood returns to the field in contention for a Region 7 title. The Raiders have won their first three region contests including a 17-6 road victory at Sprayberry on Oct. 2. Marvin Kinsey, Jr. had a game-high 70 yards rushing while Porter Sanford threw touchdown passes to Evan Crossing and Brandon Moore in the win. Riverwood’s defense held the Yellow Jackets to 107 yards of total offense.“Our defense stole the show,” Riverwood coach Ben Stready said about the Sprayberry contest. “It was one of the most dominant performances I’ve ever had the pleasure to be a part of. We knew going in that it would be a low scoring game and that we would have to be calculated on offense, taking shots when they presented themselves.”The Raiders, who have already matched last season’s win total with five victories as of Oct. 8, aren’t looking ahead to a postseason bid before the regular season ends.“We have put ourselves in a great position as far as the sub-region is concerned,” Stready said. “The playoffs is a conversation for a later date. We still have three sub-region games to play and our focus is one game at a time.”Riverwood will visit Kell in Marietta this Friday looking to give the Longhorns their second region loss of the season. Kell comes into the contest with a 4-2 record and won its last contest, a 35-6 home win over North Springs.The Longhorns hold a 3-0 lifetime series lead over the Raiders including last year’s 24-3 win.Staying in Region 7 , North Springs will make the trip to Milton and face Cambridge in a road contest on Friday. The Spartans are looking for their first region win after dropping contests to Sprayberry and Kell. Cambridge has won its first two region contests with victories over Kell and North Atlanta.Cambridge has won all three previous meetings against North Springs, defeating the Spartans 64-7 last season.Holy Spirit Prep looks to secure a spot in the Georgia Independent School Association (GISA) playoffs for the first time since 2009 with a road win over The Heritage School in Newnan on Friday. The Cougars have won two of their last three contests and have a 2-2 record in Region 1AAA. Holy Spirit Prep needs one win to get into the postseason.“This year has been ups and downs but our team motto of family has been wonderful to watch,” Cougars coach David Rosenzweig said. “This is a very tight knit group that works on the field daily to overcome our lack of size compared to other teams. The defense has played tremendously the past month allowing just 35 points in the past 3 games.”Holy Spirit Prep and The Heritage School’s lifetime series is tied 2-2 with the Hawks taking last season’s game 42-7.Westminster will host Blessed Trinity out of Roswell this Friday looking to keep pace in the Region 4AAA standings. The Wildcats dropped their region opener at Therrell 25-23 on Sept. 25. Blessed Trinity is undefeated through its first six contests this season. The Titans defeated Douglass 38-3 on Sept. 25.Westminster holds a 6-5 series lead over Blessed Trinity but the Titans have won the last four contests including a 23-11 home win last season.Mount Vernon Presbyterian hosts Landmark Christian this Saturday in a Region 5A contest. The Mustangs have already matched last season’s win total with two victories this season through Oct. 8. Mount Vernon Presbyterian defeated Cross Keys 45-7 on Sept. 18 behind three touchdown passes from Jacob Cavender. Ahmir Lee had two rushing touchdowns for the Mustangs as well.Landmark Christian out of Fairburn comes into the game with a 4-2 record. The War Eagles have won all three previous contests against the Mustangs, including a 56-21 victory last year.
